segments.text: If you want to classify, you're either going to be involved in the production of a radioactive substance, if that's your interest, or you're going to be involved in looking at the radiation that comes off the reactor itself, those parts.
The radiation that comes after the reactor itself went down in popularity?
Only because of the completion of studies of particle physics.
That was in the early 70s?
Yeah, the effort was so intense, as I said, throughout the world, that they progressed very rapidly.
The intensity definitely fell away.
Once the information is gathered, the basic information, it has not changed much.
Well, you still have people looking, and they'll change numbers a little bit.
You'll see a little change, but not much of a change.
Has the popularity of creating radioactive material or creating advanced codes or activating material, has that changed since you started?
Well, it's changed in the fact that I think there's more ingenuity in the use of these materials, particularly the medical field.
They're just really on the threshold of nuclear medicine.
It's going to become even more sophisticated, more and more uses of these materials.
We're going to see them coming up regularly now.
Japanese, for example, are doing quite well in brain cancer treatment with capture boron, boron capture work.
Whereas in the United States, we're not that far along.
There's an interest now.
It's starting.
Do you think now is the critical time period in medical?
I wouldn't say it's critical.
I don't say it's critical.
I think nuclear medicine is doing quite well.
The advances are very, very good.
But I think you may be on a threshold of really breaking through and doing a lot of things.
You could be plugging away for a while and now is the time it's going to break open.
And also, there's more interest among the medical people.
When do you think that interest began in terms of what you were doing?
years ago.
Nuclear medicine is not, the whole field is not that new.
We've had experts in nuclear medicine for many years, but a lot of it has to do with the development of good electronics.
Really advanced quite rapidly.
Computer-based analyses, things that were just too difficult to do by hand in the early days.
Too many numbers to handle, too

too many things to look at now it's done so easily with a computer so you can feed back information in a diagnostic case feed it into a computer and it will digest all that information and give you a very simple answer I think the electronics has played just as vital part as any
because the reactors have always been here.
The radioactive materials have always been available.
It's just that the technology to use them is what's really advancing.
Now, didn't the research going on at the Nuclear Science Center, wasn't it closely coordinated with the Data Processing Center in trying to use the computer for analysis when it first opened?
several of our users that become heavily involved with the computing center.
The Activation Analysis Lab, the AARL, and now the CTC.
They use this facility mainly for activating their samples, and then they count them here, put that on tape, take that information into campus, and put it on the large computers.

where they can handle more data, more information, very quickly and in a more sophisticated manner than you could if you're in the laboratory trying to handle it on a much smaller instrument that doesn't have the capability.
Yes, definitely our users get involved with the data processors.
We get involved with it when we do studies on our reactor for the operations of the reactor.
But the air reactor, you know, as far as use of it for isotope reduction and radiation work, the other nice use of this reactor is training and teaching.
You know, there's the operations side of it, how the reactors operate, training of operators for nuclear power plants, the handling of
of radioactive materials within the facility, the hands-on experience of a health physicist, the radiation policeman, as we call him, or them.
They can come to this facility, and we can let them handle radioactive materials, something they cannot get in the classroom.
How has the center been used in education today?
Oh, quite extensively.
Has it changed at all?
I'd say it has.
I'd say in the last 10 years there's considerable more interest by more departments on the campus.
It's nothing more than just an introduction.
They want to introduce the student to the reactor and what it could do.
If it's nothing more than just a tour where a professor wants to bring his class out, we're seeing more and more of that.
Because I guess some of these professors were realizing that students were going through A&M and didn't even know there was a reactor here.
Exposure is mainly to the experimenter and not directly to the student.
So we, for example, the chemistry, freshman chemistry, in one week alone, we run through something like 600 to 700 students.
Just a tool.
That happens twice a year, and the physics department does the same thing.
These are our future researchers.
If they know such a tool exists at that earliest age in their education, it's a good chance to keep that in the back of their mind and know that it's a good tool for the future in their studies.
And then we have the other educational application where you
you're involved in graduate research, the master's research, or the doctorate research.
In that case, we offer our facilities and our expertise.
And we will train the individuals in the operation of our equipment.
And when they become capable of operating that equipment on their own, we turn them loose and they do their own research.
But we are involved in the training of that individual.
A lot of our graduate students would say come from life science.
Let's take, for example, someone who's going to study the uptake of arsenic in catfish in the rivers.
He's going to do it by a nuclear method.
He's never been around a reactor.
He doesn't know anything about it.
So we have to take that individual and work with him and train him on not only how to

The instrumentation are the counting systems to analyze his samples, but to give him some idea of what's going on with the reactor, why his samples are radioactive, and so forth and so on, can help him out.
Most of our experimenters, though, have some background in working with radiation.
We do not handle a large number that have just a basic idea and
need to be taken from the very beginning of it, stepwise, right on through.
Now, they've changed the hierarchy of who you report to.
Is that just last year?
That has changed.
Okay.
Well, for many years, the first change that I recall at the Science Center was the changing
between Dr. Cochran and Dr. Randall.
Dr. Cochran just reverted back to being head of nuclear engineering.
They assigned a separate person to be director of the center.
It was that way until just recently, as far as reporting up.
To report entities, we've
always usually had some administrator there to report to.
Harry Whitmore has been the overseer of this facility for many years.
He probably can give you a very detailed history of the administration of the Science Center.
But when Dr. Porter became director, Dr. Randall reported to Harry Whitmore again for about two years.
when Dr. Erdman arrived, took the place of Dr. Cochran as the head of the department.
Tease placed Dr. Erdman in the line of administration.
I now report, well, it was Dr. Randall first when he was still here.
Dr. Randall would report to Dr. Erdman, would turn, would then go to Whitmore and then
the chain of command went up that way to Porter.
If you look at the black box in T, so to speak, the administrative block, Dr. Ervin is there now as the head of nuclear engineering research.
Because the department heads of engineering are assigned a portion of their time into T's for research.
And they are the directors of
of research for their particular field of engineering.
So in this case, they just placed Dr. Erdman there as the administrator we go for.
Has that made any difference in your operations at all?
Well, I think it has.
I think better communications, I think, compared to the last two years.
Communications with the faculty?
Entities.
Entities.
And the faculty, yes.
better progress in keeping in touch with the faculty in nuclear engineering.
There seemed to be a period there where we were not in contact that close.
Now, the Nuclear Science Center has embarked upon a new direction within the last, actually the last two years we did this.
We're now on a very large campaign to sell this facility to the university.
We feel that
We're not that well exposed.
More people need to know about us.

If the department heads know more about this facility, then the next time they look at a faculty member to come on staff on board, they may look at that faculty prospect as being a potential user of the facility.
Chemistry, there seems to be quite a bit of interest
It's been being built up over there.
We have several people that are interested in using the reactor.
It's taken several years to reach that point.
We need more involvement by engineering.
Materials testing.
We do not have a lot of interest.
Did you ever have any interest?
Yes, there's been material testing interest.
But I mean, it's been rather...
Is it small but steady?
It seems to always depend upon who is at the university.
If this person has that interest and he's at the university, then he's going to come to the center and use it.
It's very difficult to speak with a researcher who has a special interest and convince him he needs to change his interest.
That just doesn't work.
The way to do it is to hire him to do it.
bring the type of researcher to the university that would use the facility.
And that's our goal, is to work with the administrators.
Hopefully, that they would bring these type of people to Indiana.
For example, right now, Dr. Dan Hightower over at the vet school would love to see a good radio pharmaceutical expert here for the
the preparing of pharmaceuticals in medical research.
But they're basically the preparation of radioactive pharmaceuticals.
And they have to be clinically certified and so forth.
So it's not an easy thing.
And there are a lot of areas that could be researched in medical pharmaceuticals.
So that's just one example.
Was this something that the Nuclear Science Center decided would be happening, or was this something that came down to you?
No, this is TEAS.
TEAS has asked for studies, I'd say extensive studies of this facility started about four years ago by TEAS.
Now, TEAS, of course, you've got to realize they are a division that's established by the legislature to provide a research link
the industry serving the industrial requirements of the state of Texas.

That's done by working with the faculty, sharing the faculty with engineering, yeah, with the college of engineering to produce these basic research needs to improve anything within first the state and then the region.
And the Science Center is really
doing more than just that type of work, that sponsored research more to some extent.
Because we're also involved in teaching and we're also involved in education.
And we're a multi-use type facility rather than just sponsored research only.
So I can understand why TEAS is looking at us in terms of
maybe making more money for them than paying their way and stuff like that.
That seems to be the real problem within, our problem within TV journalism.
But research reactors do not make money.
They do not pay their own money.
None of them do.
No, they don't.
They're not that way.
They're operated by the university systems as teaching, training, and research tools, and they're
They're just an educational expense and research expense that's realized.
That's the framework of most of the reactors.
Well, most.
Certainly the majority.
Is it a similar problem to what the data processing centers have in terms of they will ?
I think so, but again, it's a...
But they're an educational expense and a training expense.
Right.
You're probably, in your work in interviewing people with NTs,
you will find that their philosophy is that they are more than willing to develop research capabilities.
But once those research capabilities are developed, good, sound research projects, as far as they're concerned, have enough sponsorship behind that research to pay for the facility's operation.
And that's where this facility has a problem.
because it takes specially trained people to operate a reactor.
So we're a little heavy on the administrative and engineer side because there's quite a bit of responsibility.
We're involved in safety.
We have to do everything by strict requirements, the regulations that are established by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
We must comply with those, and that takes a lot of our time.
We must be aware of any new regulations to our administrators.
We spend time commenting, attending meetings, discussing things with the NRC.
They're a regulatory agency, and you must have an input.
If you do not speak up, you're going to be regulated to the point where you can't do anything.
So you have to defend yourself, is what I'm saying.
And to defend yourself takes a lot of time.
It sure does.
Now, back on the education side, you must realize too that we do have the laboratory instruction.
Nuclear engineering labs are conducted here.
These are usually the type of laboratory where each week the student will perform an experiment.
It can be done within a four hour period.
either a study of the behavior of the reactor, or he may be dealing with just other things I've been speaking of, an isotope production experiment, or maybe even a beam extraction experiment.
Has this always been the case in terms of being used as a lab?
Yes, it varies in intensity, again, depending on faculty.
There are some faculty that would be very interested in doing the experiments here.
And then if that course is assigned to a different professor, there's a good chance that he has other ideas or other plans for the course.
And he wouldn't use the reactor as much as the previous professor.
How do you do nuclear experiments without a reactor?
You don't.
Oh, yeah, there are laboratories.
purchase sources and do...
If you're having your students do labs...
Okay, they're just doing something different.
They're not getting this knowledge.
That's true.
They'd have to be learning something different.
True.
But they can deal with radioactivity in a laboratory by purchasing sources.
But...
If you're going to study the behavior of a reactor, then you obviously must have a reactor.
That's the one thing.
Of course, I feel very strongly that you're going to have a much better educated engineer coming out of this system in nuclear engineering if he's been associated with a reactor.
Some knowledge of it.
how it operates, what you can do with him, and the do's and don'ts in terms of his safety, his personnel safety.
Because he may be stepping right into a facility, and if he's had no experience or actual training of working with radioactivity, he may be a weak engineer for a while.
He may be a little careless about what he's doing.
He may not appreciate the effects of radiation on his body.
He may do things that aren't too careful.
Or he may be so scared of it, either way, it could go either way you want to.
So afraid of it, he doesn't want to do his work.
Because we try to show the student that if you follow procedures,
and you have a basic knowledge of radiation, you can work with it very safely if you're level-headed and just follow rules.
That's exactly the way we operate out here.
We do everything by following rules.
We operate a reactor that way.
We conduct our experiments that way.
We have auditing and monitoring of just about everything we do.
You're talking about...
the highest regulated field of research or industry there is.
No one's ever died in a nuclear power plant from radiation.
They've fallen off ladders and broken arms and legs and things like that, but the only accidents we've had in the nuclear field have been in the laboratories or in experimental reactors.
Our military is heavily involved in reactors, in submarines and surface ships.
We've had reactors that have gone to the Arctic and they're dropped in sections from airplanes and they're put together on the ice.
All types of development of reactors.
The early scientists that were developing weapons, they've had some accidents.
But the industry, the nuclear power industry, has not experienced that kind of an accident, no doubt.
Has this particular facility had any problems with ?
No.
We're very fortunate.
We have a very understanding community.
People in this community, the state of Texas even, if you want to include the whole state,
are highly supportive of research.
They just don't have that.
There's a small group called the Armadillo Force that have shown some demonstrations at the nuclear power plants.
But that's only because of a pickup from what they, you get these ideas from the newspapers and the press.
But you've not had any demonstrations here throughout your history?
No.
No?
We just went through our re-licensing of this facility, which continues our license for another 20 years.
And in that re-licensing process, our license and our application appears in the public document room in Washington.
And there were no interveners, no questions asked at all on the material we submitted and what we were going to do with the reactor.
State of California, that's a completely different picture.
The UCLA reactor, they're trying to re-license and they have interveners.
It's really a mess.
It's all tied up in legal matters now.
They're going to shut that reactor down during the Olympics for fear of a terrorist target.
The only reason it's a target is because it's been in the news.
If you broadcast these things and point them out, then you're going to have problems.
But as long as you have a very calm, understanding community, then you're okay.
We've had several articles through the years telling our general public that we're not an environmental force or impact at all in this community.
And we monitor that very carefully.
We have to put extensive reports into the NRC, into the state of Texas concerning the environment that we may have a part of, an effect upon.
We monitor the creeks for any radioactivity, the grass, the dirt samples around for several miles.
Monitor the milk at the dairy up here for any traces of radioactivity that could
to be associated either with this facility or any other.

If you compare that to this power plant over here, Gibbons Creek, that's going to be burning lignite, they're going to be puffing all kinds of radioactivity up that stack of natural radioactivity that's been dug out of the earth, but it's going to be discharged in such a way that it comes out of their concentration because there's uranium in that dirt, in that coal.
And that uranium is going to go up that stack.
So they're going to have far more environmental impact than we would at this facility.
Because the byproduct we have that goes up our stack around research reactors, it's a gas.
It's contained in air.
It's argon that's in air.
And we produce a radioactive material any time air gets around the reactor.
because there's argon in there.
But the argon has a very short half-life.
It doesn't stay around very long.
In fact, in a matter of something like five hours, it's roughly 90% gone.
And we discharge it at a high altitude.
It disperses at a very, very low level.
In fact, it's so low once it leaves our facility that we can't even detect it.
We must detect it
inside the facility when it's concentrated for us to even know that we're releasing it.
It's that low.
There's not a threat at all.
Have you noticed any change in use of facilities or attitudes towards the facilities with administrative changes in the university?
We didn't see many changes.
Basically until, I'd say, the changing between Benson and Porter.
I think that was the most drastic change in looking at our operation.
I think it's typical of that administration.
They looked, as you said, they looked at the data processing center.
I'm sure they're looking at places like the wind tunnel.
In fact, right now, we're under a review.
There are several considerations that Tiege looks at.
The refueling of a reactor that's been in the newspapers.
You might have seen the article related to that.
The concerns of the commission are that we may become targets of terrorists.
Well, this would bother any administration.
If I were Dr. Porter, I'd be concerned because he's licensee.
So it's up to me to keep him properly informed.
Because a lot of things you read in the newspapers sometimes are scary tactics.
If you know a little bit more about it, you can sit down and think it through and be reasonable about it.
You have a better control.
There has been action by one of the commissioners
to try to more or less scare our administrators into shutting down our reactors.
He puts out this information that we have nuclear, we have bomb material in our facilities.
It's not true.
The terrorists cannot take what we have without a considerable degree of difficulty.
He would have to
to really work at it, to come up with a weapon.
I mean, he would have to almost be a major power to do it.
A small nation couldn't do it.
It's just too sophisticated, too complicated.
It's not the right material.
That's the first thing.
And that's what I tried to point out in my conversations to the public around why we're not a terrorist target.
are a theft target of this field.
Research reactors are.
As a service facility, what does TEAS do for you?
What does it do for us?
Well, first of all, it's the parent funding we have.
That's the main thing.
But TEAS has an interest in serving the university and serving industry in Texas.
Through that philosophy, we have a facility that can do that.
And that's why we've always been a part of TEAS.
We have the type of research facility that's suited for sponsored research, government research, industrial.
And if you bring those kind of dollars into the system through TEAS, that allows you to place
the faculty member in that budget, some graduate students, purchase of equipment, things of that nature.
So if you look at T's side of it, that's what they want to do.
The research reactors, in our case, we spend a lot of our time on teaching and training.
We just do not have that many sponsored research programs.
The only way to get them, as I said before, is to have the faculty members here that can generate that type of interest.
And it's improving.
There's some researchers now in the Department of Engineering that have some very good proposals.
I can remember that sometimes there were no
There wasn't a single proposal from engineering.
Well, back in, I'd say, mid-'70s or early-'70s, we were doing most of our work for other disciplines.
College of Science, we were doing a lot of geological work, chemistry, biochemistry, life sciences, veterinary medicine, but not much in engineering.
If you look at the Science Center's position, it's more oriented to be a university division than it may be a TEAS division.
But TEAS has always been the parent administration.
This study we're going through now, there have been proposals in these studies that say
to move us within the university, much like today's processing center.
Look at our funding.
These are the things that we're working on, Dr. Irvin and the staff out here.
That study's going on right now.
I don't know how much of it you can publish or put together.
possibly terminate before you're through and you can say something about it.
Right now, I can say it's a study.
And there's several considerations.
There's several things that could affect you.
Well, TEAS is reevaluating a lot of its programs just to see if it's serving the way it should be.
That's right.
In this case, it may not be serving as it should.
We may not be serving the
tease parent organizations based on their philosophy.
Because of the expense of operating the facility, they would prefer to operate where we either paid our way or almost all of it.
At least 90%, say.
Based on that philosophy I gave you earlier, once you develop a research capability, solid
sound research practices would be to subsidize, or pay for the subsidy of that unit.
Well, data processing around that, getting out of T's and becoming state subsidized.
That may be the way we go.
Oh, I think so.
Definitely, in the proposals, there have been statements of becoming a line item out of
state budget.
There are many things.
If the university system feels that this facility should be operated on a subsidy basis, and they want to have the state funded directly, then that's a way to go.
Is there anything else you'd like to tell me about the particular projects you remember here?
Oh, well, okay.
Now, if you want to talk about the
The fun things, yeah.
Sure, tell me the fun things.
Well, the fun thing, I would classify them as the animal experiments.
First, in the early days, I'd say late 60s, when we had our first reactor type here, a lower power than we have now, we were doing some goatee radiations.
That's Sidney Brown's stuff?
Yes, the goats.
And we didn't have the...
large radiation cell that we have now.
And we would bundle that goat up in a tow sack, just a little small bundle, his legs wrapped over his head and all sorts of things.
And then we would shove that animal upward in through an opening toward the reactor, close the door and then bring the reactor up for exposure.
And then they would bring the animal out after
Of course, we moved away with the reactor and cleared the radiation.
And then they would take the animal over to the laboratory next door here and had the animal go through an obstacle course.
And the poor thing, once he got out of the tow sack, it would take him an hour just to get his legs back, even if he were well.
So I thought that was quite interesting.
Measurements were not that accurate at the time.
Those became quite sophisticated compared to the goats.
As we later started our work with the Brooks Medical Center in San Antonio, the irradiation of baboons and monkeys, mainly monkeys, reesey monkeys.
These are done in our large radiation cell.
Very fascinating experiments because the animals are highly trained and they perform very difficult tasks.
They must perform them very quickly.
And once they've been irradiated, provided a lethal dose of radiation, then they are monitored for their function, as well as the vital organs of the body are checked and monitored.
And it's very interesting to watch those experiments.
Of course, the animal is not allowed to suffer a radiation death.
This is a laboratory animal.
Our lamb animals are usually put to sleep, as they were in the case of the monkeys.
And the baboon is a similar thing.
These were studies that were being made to determine man's performance.
How would man be able to function after a lethal dose of radiation, particularly a military application.
The fighter pilot that
It's not blown out of the sky, but he receives a lethal dose from a nuclear warhead or something, or he flies through a nuclear radiation field or something and receives a lethal dose.
What do you do?
Do you bring him back home, or do you let him perform his mission?
That's the information thereafter.
The other interesting part thereafter, though,
They were trying to determine if there was any chemical treatments or injections into the vital organs that could change their functions once they were subjected to that much radiation.
So there were a lot of pre-radiation surgery experiments, implants of capillary tubes and injection points in the animals, particularly the brain.
to see if they could improve the brain functions after an exposure like that.
I'd say of all the experiments we've done, those are the most interesting, mainly because of the animals, I guess, and what they could do.
They're very clever little fellows.
It's unbelievable.
And each animal was valued at about $15,000 an animal because of the training.
Oh, yeah, they could fly teeter sticks like an airplane.
They had a seat they were in, and the computer would tilt the seat.
If it tilted more than 30 degrees, then they would get shocked.
So when it started tilting, they had a little stick just like an airplane.
If the seat was tilting farther, they'd pull back.
If the seat tilted to the left, they'd throw the stick to the right.
They'd do everything they could to get that seat back level.
So they wouldn't get shot?
Oh, yeah.
Perfectly level.
And they could do it very quickly.
And they had a very excellent sense of color and pattern descriptions.
Some of the animals were trained to look at a series of patterns, four patterns placed in front of them, mainly squares of different colors.
very difficult to distinguish if you had a red, red, white, yellow, or whether you had a red, yellow, white, blue, you know, be that close, he'd have to distinguish.
And then he would give a single frame down below and let him look at it for about seven seconds.
And then he would have to match, once that went off, went outside, he would have to match that same frame
within another seven seconds by touching the right picture.
So he was coordinating the colors as well as the patterns.
And to do it that rapidly, it's very difficult.
And is there any animal research going on right now?
No, we're not doing those now.
Those experiments have terminated.
But funding went out on it.
Oh, we were doing those up until about six years ago.
They would come up two or three times a year.
They have a full team of physicians, veterinarians, technicians, and they bring all their equipment.
All we can do again, once again, is provide them with a reactor.
Well, the other thing that we think is exciting about our reactor is the pulsing of the reactor.
We were exposing these animals by pulsing.
Our reactor can operate two ways.
It can operate at a steady power, or we can place it in the pulse mode and put it on an excursion.
It goes on a power excursion, but it shuts itself down by a nuclear technique because it doesn't last very long when it goes on the power excursion.
The order of milliseconds, in other words.
And we have no capability of shutting it off that quickly unless it shuts itself off.
So this is all built into the technology of the fuel.
And that's why we changed fuel back in 1969.
We changed from the initial fuel and went to a more sophisticated research reactor fuel called Triga.
T-R-I-G-A in San Diego.
They're the manufacturers of it and developers of it.
And we've been a Triga reactor ever since.
And then that's when you got the capability to pulse?
That's when we went into the capability of pulsing and also we upgraded the power by a factor of 10.
We went from a 100 kilowatt reactor to a 1 megawatt reactor, steady steady.
And when you do that, your capability of producing these isotopes jumps tenfold automatically because there are 10 times as many neutrons.
So what we were doing before
In 10 hours, we could now do in one hour, as far as total time.
That's what's nice about that.
But there's still a technical break.
